column4:
@W_R_Chase @GoHugoIO @DrMowinckels @ma_salmon I think the most important are:

+ 2 step process (knitting just does Rmd -> md; hugo just does md -> site)
+ knitting is done intentionally by user, avoiding issues w/ modified time and serve site attempting ‚Äúmega-knit‚Äù
+ html widgets work better, deps get loaded per page

column4:
Working with zipped csvs? vroom not working because one of those files is borked? 

Iterate through them bad larrys with this little combo of purr and vroom

purrr::map(
    fs::dir_ls(), 
    purrr::possibly(
        vroom::vroom,
        otherwise = tibble::tibble()))

column6: The data prison. The default table crowds out your data with non-data-ink and locks your data into cells. Look for opportunities to free your data from their prison and remove the visual noise to let your data and the relationships between them shine out. Concept: @EdwardTufte https://t.co/CIoqhsapA9

If you use the hugo academic theme in #rstats #blogdown and the featured img isn't fully shown, here's a simple trick to fix it. 
üñåÔ∏èOpen it with Paint 3D (all PCs have it)
üñºÔ∏èGo to canvas & add transparent padding
üìèMake sure the aspect ratio is ~ 1.3 (4X3)

@VizMonkey My quick heuristic:

‚úÖ Use ~ when you call a function using ()
      e.g. map(x, ~ select(., -Species))

column4:
Try to use -> (not <-)  for #rstats dplyr assignments!
1. It matches how we think: 
input %>% transformed %>% more transformed -> output
2. It helps running code in the console as you develop it: you always need to run the beginning of a chunk and not assigning shows what you get

- create_from_github("user/repo")
- pr_init("name-of-new-branch")
- [edit code]
- pr_push()
- [wait for merge]
- pr_finish()

column4:
üì¶ @_lionelhenry on how to write functions in the tidyverse:
1. Use [[ ]] : function(data, var) select(data, .data[[ var ]])
2. Pass the dots: function(data, ...) { data %>% count(...) }
3. Use the new curly bracket operator: function(data, var) select(data, {{var}})

column4:
Tip for debugging plots (in ggplot2) from @ClausWilke: 

1. Save your plot (for example, as 'figure')
2. Call layer_plot(figure)

Now you can see the data that ggplot2 is using to generate your plot to help you debug! #rstats https://t.co/zrFLu6GODN

column4: Today is #rmarkdown day. My #knitr trick is `read_chunk`. I separate my #rstats scripts from the md document for a large proj. Bc I usually write R code first and then document the analysis. `read_chunk` reads the external R chunks into the md. It forces you to name the chunk. https://t.co/JuvNW9Lxe6

One of my favorite ggplot2 tricks, which I learned on the @R4DScommunity Slack group: add "NULL" to the end of your ggplot chain so you can comment out a command without ending with a "+" E.g.
ggplot(diamonds, aes(price)) + 
geom_point() +
# geom_density() + 
NULL
